trans-unit.source: The .NET ecosystem has a concept of frameworks.
trans-unit.target: The .NET ecosystem has a concept of frameworks.

trans-unit.source: Frameworks define the API that you can use to target a particular platform.
trans-unit.target: Frameworks define the API that you can use to target a particular platform.

trans-unit.source: The .NET Framework 4.6 is one of those platforms.
trans-unit.target: The .NET Framework 4.6 is one of those platforms.

trans-unit.source: Frameworks are used in Visual Studio and other IDEs and editors to provide you with the correct set of APIs.
trans-unit.target: Frameworks are used in Visual Studio and other IDEs and editors to provide you with the correct set of APIs.

trans-unit.source: They are also used by NuGet, for both production and consumption of NuGet packages, to ensure that you produce and use appropriate packages (and underlying assets) for the framework you are targeting.
trans-unit.target: They are also used by NuGet, for both production and consumption of NuGet packages, to ensure that you produce and use appropriate packages (and underlying assets) for the framework you are targeting.

trans-unit.source: One can think of frameworks as one of the key currencies in the .NET ecosystem.
trans-unit.target: One can think of frameworks as one of the key currencies in the .NET ecosystem.

trans-unit.source: The concept is there for correctness, to help you and your customers seeing [MissingMethodException](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.MissingMethodException) and friends at runtime.
trans-unit.target: The concept is there for correctness, to help you and your customers seeing [MissingMethodException](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.MissingMethodException) and friends at runtime.

trans-unit.source: The table below defines the set of frameworks that you can use, how they are referred to and which version of the [.NET Standard Library](library.md) that they implement.
trans-unit.target: The table below defines the set of frameworks that you can use, how they are referred to and which version of the [.NET Standard Library](library.md) that they implement.

trans-unit.source: Note: These framework versions are the latest stable versions.
trans-unit.target: Note: These framework versions are the latest stable versions.

trans-unit.source: There may be pre-released versioned as well that are not described by this table.
trans-unit.target: There may be pre-released versioned as well that are not described by this table.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple ways to refer to frameworks in written form, most of which are used in this documentation.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple ways to refer to frameworks in written form, most of which are used in this documentation.

trans-unit.source: They are described below, both as a legend for interpreting the documentation but also to guide use in other documents.
trans-unit.target: They are described below, both as a legend for interpreting the documentation but also to guide use in other documents.

trans-unit.source: Using .NET Framework 4.6.1 as an example, the following forms can be used:
trans-unit.target: Using .NET Framework 4.6.1 as an example, the following forms can be used:

trans-unit.source: You can refer to a .NET platform or runtime.
trans-unit.target: You can refer to a .NET platform or runtime.

trans-unit.source: You can refer to a framework or targeting of a framework using long- or short-forms of the TFM.
trans-unit.target: You can refer to a framework or targeting of a framework using long- or short-forms of the TFM.

trans-unit.source: Both are equally valid in the general case.
trans-unit.target: Both are equally valid in the general case.

trans-unit.source: Referring to a family of Frameworks
trans-unit.target: Referring to a family of Frameworks

trans-unit.source: You can refer to a family of frameworks using long- or short-forms of the framework ID.
trans-unit.target: You can refer to a family of frameworks using long- or short-forms of the framework ID.

trans-unit.source: Bother are equally valid in the general case.
trans-unit.target: Bother are equally valid in the general case.
